messageBody:
> FWIW, I use J.B.'s methodology, /and/ I like to fit all of my tests for
> a given class into a single TestCase. I find that in a multi-developer
> environment, it's simply too difficult for everyone to keep track of
> where every test for a given class is located if the tests are scattered.

I understand, although with proper naming conventions and "packaging",
it's not that hard to keep track of who's who... I also like to
mention all the TestCases related to a class using @see tags in the
JavaDoc header of the class.

> In my primary TestCase (J.B.'s 'ATest' class), the suite()
> implementation adds the test suites of all the interface-specific tests, so
>
> public static Test suite() {
> TestSuite suite = new TestSuite(ATest.class);
> suite.addTestSuite(AAsXTest.suite());
> suite.addTestSuite(AAsYTest.suite());
> suite.addTestSuite(AAsZTest.suite());
> return suite;
> }

From the JavaDoc I understand I'll have to choose between
addTest(AAsXTest.suite()) and addTest(AAsXTest.class)

Are those solutions exactly the same if my suite() method is as follows ?

public static Test suite() {
return new TestSuite(AAsYTest.class);
}


>
> I also implement each of the '...As...Test' classes as static inner
> classes of my main TestCase.

Ok, I think I get the idea.

So a main TestCase might look like:

import junit.framework.Test;
import junit.framework.TestCase;
import junit.framework.TestSuite;

public class ATest extends TestCase {

public static void main(String[] args) {
junit.swingui.TestRunner.main(new String[] { ATest.class.getName() });
}

public static Test suite() {
TestSuite suite = new TestSuite(ATest.class);
suite.addTestSuite(AAsXTest.class);
suite.addTestSuite(AAsYTest.class);
return suite;
}

public ATest(String name) {
super(name);
}

public void testSomeSpecficABehavior() {
// Please behave! Remember you're an A...
}

public static class AAsXTest extends TestCase {

public void testSomeSpecficXBehavior() {
// Look I'm an X!
}
}

public static class AAsYTest extends TestCase {

public void testSomeSpecficYBehavior() {
// And I'm an Y!
}
}
}

This works beautifully. I really like the look of the hierarchy in
the JUnit Swing TestRunner.

My only "problem" is: in Eclipse, when I run this "file" using the
<ALT+SHIFT+D, T> shortcut (debug as JUnit test which I tend to use all
the time) I get a dialog which lets me choose between the main class
and the static inner classes (which must be public in order for JUnit
to extract the fixtures). Is there a way to disable it in order to run
the main class every time ?
